question: Why do we have separate tax brackets ? Would n't it be easier if we had a flat percentage taken out across the board for individuals ? . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["There is a concept of marginal utility -- the first dollar is more important than later dollars . If you are homeless , having a dumpy studio is a more beneficial than middle manager being able to upgrade from a 3BR house to a 5BR house . Having food to eat is more important than whether you eat chicken breast or splurge on the steak . And so on ... So the lower earnings dollars are more critical to the basic necessities of life and are thus taxed at a lower rate than dollars earned where they are going to be spent on qualitative enhancements rather than necessities . To keep a tax rate even among all income , then you 'd need to tax people making minimum wage way more then they pay today , when they are already living paycheck to paycheck and struggling to make ends meet -- all while taxing lower taxes from those making six , seven , eight figures or more . Does it sound fair for somebody making $ 15k pay more taxes while cutting the taxes of somebody making $ 1.5 million ? So if you earned $ 50k and somebody else made $ 500k , you 'd both pay the same rate on the first $ 50k earned .", "There are two basic justifications for this . First , the idea is that in terms of the impact on someone 's lifestyle of losing a larger percentage of their income matters less as income increases . Second , and related , is that lower - income people are more likely to spend their money , and so taxing it at the same rate reduces economic demand .", 'Tax brackets are simple way to create a progressive tax . The brackets are a simplification a alternative like a continuous mathematical function to calculate the tax for the income . The motivation of a progressive tax it that a flat tax is a higher budon for people with low income . Everyone need to spend money on the basic things needed to survive like food , housing etc . So a higher tax is is a higher budon for someone that make precisely enough to survive then for a person with twice the income and obvious less a budon for someone with ten time the income . A progressive tag is constructed so every one pays the same tax for the first $ 100 they earn regardless of their total income but the tax rate will be higher for the next $ 100 ( the amounts are just a example ) Som people might argue that a flat tax is more fare the a progressive tag . You could motivate the alternative and the amount the tax increases with income . But to say that we should use flat tax because it is a bit simpler to calculate it not a good way to motivate it . Argue instead for fairness or the ability for a person to pay tax not de difficulty of a simple calculation . To make tax simple you should have tax systems like it is often done in Europe . The tax form include most information already and for a significant part of the population the correct way for them to submit their taxes is to only sign the form .']

This means that people who earn more money pay a higher percentage of their income in taxes, while people who earn less pay a lower percentage. This helps to reduce income inequality and ensure that everyone pays their fair share."]

question: How are tunnels that go underwater built ? I do n't understand how they are built underwater at all especially the older ones . Explain like I'm five.

You click a link , type in a URL , select a bookmark , etc . - Your browser sends sends some data to the web server , specifying the page to load ( " HTTP request " ) . - The web server will load the HTML file from memory or disk , or generate it using server - side scripts , and send that file to your browser ( " HTTP response " ) . - Your browser will read that HTML to determine what all the parts of it mean ( " parsing " ) . If the HTML file contains links to external files , such as images , scripts , stylesheets , or applets , then your browser will send requests for those files to the server . - Meanwhile , it will start the process of turning that page into graphical output on your screen ( " rendering " ) . - When the server receives more requests , it will load the requested files and send them on to your browser . - When your browser receives those other files , it will incorporate them into the rendering process as appropriate . If it takes more than a very short time to receive the stylesheet after the HTML has been received , then the browser may initially render the page without the style information . Note that if you request more than one page from the same server , and they link to the same stylesheet , then your browser will usually keep the stylesheet around after the first request rather than asking for it anew ( " caching " ) . This saves a request , which saves time and bandwidth . The server will usually include a code of sorts when it sends you a file indicating how long that file will be up - to - date ( the " expiry " ) , so that your browser knows when it \'s time to request a new one . EXAMPLE : I click on a link to URL_0 . My browser sends the following message to the server at URL_1 on port 80 : GET /helloworld.html HTTP/1.1 Host : URL_1 The server receives this message , sees that I want to see helloworld.html , loads it from disk , and includes it in a response : HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content - Type : text / html ; charset="utf-8 " Content - Length : 234 < ! " in large white Georgia on a blue background . By using responsive design, the website can automatically adjust itself to look good and be easy to use on different devices.

Here's a simple way to explain it: Imagine that you have a toy box and you want to put all of your toys inside. If you have a small toy box, you might have to stack the toys on top of each other to make them all fit. But if you have a bigger toy box, you can spread the toys out and they will all fit comfortably. That's kind of like what responsive design does for websites - it adjusts the layout so that everything fits comfortably on different devices.']

chatgpt_answers: ['Native American history is taught in many schools, although the depth and breadth of this teaching can vary. It is true that Native American cultures and histories have not always been well-represented or understood in mainstream education. There are several reasons for this. Another reason is that the histories and cultures of Native American peoples have often not been well-documented or preserved. This is due in part to the fact that many Native American cultures were oral cultures, meaning that they passed down their histories and traditions through stories, songs, and other forms of oral tradition rather than through written records. This can make it more difficult to learn about Native American history compared to the histories of other groups that have more extensive written records. Finally, the histories and cultures of Native American peoples have often been impacted by trauma and violence, including forced removal from their lands, assimilation into mainstream culture, and the loss of many traditional ways of life. This has made it more challenging to preserve and pass on Native American histories and traditions. Overall, it is important to recognize and learn about the diverse histories and cultures of Native American peoples, and to work to ensure that these histories are accurately and respectfully represented in mainstream education.']

question: Why has n't China started phasing out symbolic writing and started standardizing phonetic ( pinyin 拼音 ) writing ? Would n't standardized pinyin as the primary written communication make it easier for Westerners to learn Chinese and for the Chinese to learn English ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["Part of it is that while there is a unified Chinese * written * language , there are dozens ( maybe hundreds , I do n't know for sure ) of difference * spoken * Chinese languages ( i.e. dialects ) . Pinyin corresponds to Mandarin Chinese ( the official spoken language ) while there are many other dialects ( Cantonese , Shanghainese , Fujianese , etc . ) which will have the same written form as Mandarin , but are spoken completely differently . Having a unified character language makes things easier when communicating between different dialects .", "Yes but changing a few billion people 's written language for the sake of making it easier to learn a different language is n't something the Chinese government seems especially keen on doing .", "There 's quite a lot of writing in the old format -- several millenia of classic literature , history , and philosophy . As long as that writing system is still in common use , all of those books are relatively accessible to the population at large . If you change writing systems , suddenly you have a cultural divide between the present and the past . China does not want a culture divide between the present and the past . Its ability to function as a country is dependent on people perceiving themselves as part of the gigantic country of China . Part of that identity is continuity with the thousands of years of culture . The Chinese government implicitly takes legitimacy by association with the traditions that preceded it ( notwithstanding actual resemblance to those traditions ) . Breaking off from history may lead to a new cultural identity , and potentially one that is fragmented or locally - based rather than nationally unified . That is something the Chinese government wants to avoid ."]
chatgpt_answers:
['Pinyin is actually a standardized system for writing Chinese using the Roman alphabet, and it is widely used in China for teaching Chinese as a second language, transcribing proper nouns and place names, and as a tool for inputting Chinese characters on computers and phones. 
However, Pinyin is not used as the primary written form of Chinese. Chinese characters (also known as Hanzi or Kanji in Japanese) are the primary written form of Chinese and have a long history dating back over 3,000 years. They are still used today because they are an important part of Chinese culture and history, and they are also very efficient for written communication. 
One of the main reasons that Pinyin is not used as the primary written form of Chinese is that it cannot fully represent the sounds and meanings of Chinese words. Chinese characters, on the other hand, can convey the full meaning and pronunciation of a word in a single character. For example, the Chinese character for "water" is 水, which is pronounced "shui" in Mandarin. Pinyin cannot represent the meaning of the character, only the pronunciation. 
Additionally, replacing Chinese characters with Pinyin as the primary written form of Chinese would be a massive undertaking that would involve changing the way that Chinese is taught in schools, updating dictionaries and other reference materials, and potentially requiring people to learn a new writing system. It would also be difficult to determine a standard way to represent the many different regional accents and dialects of Chinese using the Roman alphabet. 
In summary, while Pinyin is a useful tool for learning Chinese and transcribing proper nouns, it is not used as the primary written form of Chinese because it cannot fully represent the sounds and meanings of Chinese words, and replacing Chinese characters with Pinyin would be a major undertaking.']

question: What happens if you break a bone and do n't go to hospital with it . Assuming there is no splitting of the skin . Your wrist for example . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["Is n't this an AskReddit post ? Do you really need to have it explained like you 're five ?", "I met a guy a few years back who had broken his right arm in 2 places , about half way between the wrist and elbow ( the breaks were only 2inches or so apart ) . He did n't go to the hospital -- no insurance , no money , illegal immigrant -- ended up his arm healed after a few months , but his arm was bent way out of shape . Literally , his arm was almost a Z. He had limited usage of his fingers because of the way the tendons were situated afterwards and had a pretty limited range of motion for his wrist . He became predominantly left handed , as would be expected . I will have to try and dig up a picture of it ( if I still have the pic , that is ) . TL;DR , just go to the hospital . It can seriously fuck you up otherwise .", "Think of your bone as a bridge . When you break the bone , it 's like breaking the bridge in the middle . Now the bridge will automatically start adding concrete to the break from either side until it eventually comes back together . If you move the ends of the bridge , there will be concrete moving in every different direction ( secondary bone healing ) . If you aim the two ends of the bridge right at each other , or even put them back together with a cast , when the bridge adds more concrete , it wo n't have to add a lot and can heal quickly ( primary bone healing ) . If you never stop moving the two ends of the bridge , the bridge will never come back together , as shown in the video here with the humerus fracture . The only point of a cast is to stop the two edges of bone from moving . Same with screws and plates ( internal fixation ) . It 's like connecting the bridge edges together with steel beams so that the bridge does not move at all , allowing the concrete to fill in directly with no movement . After the concrete fills in , you can either keep the steel plates or remove then , and you can remove the cast because it 's no longer needed . Bone heals in 4 - 6 weeks when immobilized ."]
chatgpt_answers: ["If you break a bone and don't go to the hospital, it means that the bone is not being treated by a doctor. This can be a problem because the bone may not heal correctly. When a bone is broken, the body tries to fix it by creating new cells to mend the break. These new cells eventually turn into new bone, which helps the broken bone heal. However, if the bone is not properly aligned while it is healing, it may heal in the wrong position. This can cause the bone to be weaker and more prone to breaking again in the future. It can also cause the joint to not work properly, which can make it difficult to use your hand or wrist. If you think you have broken a bone, it's important to see a doctor as soon as possible. The doctor will be able to tell you if you have a broken bone and how to best treat it so that it can heal properly."]

question: How does comedy writing work ? Comedians who write bits and jokes and what not . What is the process which goes into the development of a bit ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['It is much easier to find something funny about a topic than to simply come up with a funny thing on its own . Have you noticed how jokes effortlessly come to you in conversation ? It \'s because ideas are being thrown around , and your brain is automatically making connections with other stuff you know in the background . When trying to come up with jokes , the trick is to start from concepts , and only then craft comedy out of it . & nbsp ; Let \'s go with * * Dogs * * . I \'ll list some arbitrary facts about them . 1 . They are loyal to their owners regardless of the situation 2 . They eat disgusting things if given the opportunity 3 . They have a warped sense of time 4 . They ca n\'t eat chocolate 5 . Small ones are often more aggresive than larger ones 6 . They smell each others \' butts as a greeting 7 . They get happy and jittery very easily 8 . They hate the mailman 9 . They have a pack mentality & nbsp ; As you write concepts down , some straightforward bits might start forming on their own . 4 and 2 connect for a very obvious joke - the fact that dogs eat disgusting stuff all the time , but will get very sick if they eat a piece of chocolate . > Dogs make no sense . They will eat their own poop and vomit , spoiled food and all sorts of nasty shit and be fine - but give them a bit of chocolate ? They fucking die . > Like , " Oh man , this dead pigeon tastes delicious ! But do n\'t give me that chocolate shit , that \'s disgusting " & nbsp ; It \'s also a good idea to list inherently funny things related to a topic , and potential double entendres and wordplays to use : 1 . Dogs that make for funny mental images : * Chihuahuas , Pugs , Poodles * 2 . ~~Funny~~ Staple Dog Names : * Fido , Rex * ( Thanks /u / rewboss ! ) 3 . Potential double entendre : * Bitch * 4 . Potential wordplay : * Hot Dog * & nbsp ; For the next bit , I \'ll use number 6 with a funny dog name and a reference to the previous joke : > Is n\'t it weird how dogs sniff each other \'s butts as a way to greet each other ? " What up Fido ? Smelling good today ! Had some dead pigeon last night , huh ? " & nbsp ; Of course , if you want a lot of jokes , you will need a much longer list . You can search for more facts online , use or make up related stories , and keep adding more wordplay material . Referencing a previous joke is always a good idea , too . As you expand your list , new bits will form at an astonoshing rate . & nbsp ; Last but not least , remember that jokes will always seem stale on paper - the delivery is very important for them to work . In order to get good with that , you may want to watch some stand - up comedians do their magic . & nbsp ; * EDIT : Formatting * * EDIT 2 : This method is a simplification of something I learned from a [ Jerry Corley video ] ( URL_0 ) *', 'I define comedy as an intersection between reality and absurdity . You \'re essentially asking about what comedy is . A lot of old definitions hark back to such ideas ( young versus old , for instance ) . Comedians , specifically some of the best , talk about absurdities in reality , or inject absurdity into reality by taking turns you would n\'t expect . A lot of times it \'s about breaking the cooperative principle of language - which is to say , when people communicate , they \'re cooperating . Otherwise nothing they say would make sense . If you ask for the time and I say my phone is dead , years ago that would have made no sense . But now it does , and you have to cooperate intrinsically to understand that I \'m helping you with more information . Comedians often break these rules on purpose to mislead people from reality into absurdity . They set up a premise , and then " tweak it " . How an individual comedian works though , that can change . You \'d have to ask comedians themselves . I \'d love to try stand - up myself but I just never found the time or courage thus far .', 'I \'m an aspiring comedian . 26 y / o and I \'ve been writing one - liner jokes my whole life , I have 4 or 5 thousand . As far as " comedy writing " you do n\'t plan on performing goes , just get a piece of paper and pen and start writing , like \' free styling \' and never let the pen stop moving . Try to be funny in your stream of thought and fill out a page . This overall makes you a funnier person , when you look back and reread it you \'ll see 6 or 7 \' concepts \' that you can now reword more succinctly into a joke . It also sharpens your mind so that you can be funny more consistently and for longer , and that will reflect in your spoken words in conversation . As far as writing one - liner jokes go , see an object that you find peculiar , then just think about it , think about what relates to it , think of what is obscure about it and then put it one sentence . After you write 500 of those , spanning many different topics , pick out the 50 best ones or pair the jokes that share a common topic and reword them ( if possible ) so they fit more like a puzzle piece . This is how I do it and I think this is how Mitch Hedberg did it . When he says 3 one - liners in a row that are all on the same topic , it \'s likely that he wrote them at 3 different times , maybe years apart . This is an essential part of being a comedian , holding as many jokes in your working memory that you can and then recalling them upon the realization that they mesh well with other jokes/ topics , or saying them aloud in conversation ( it seemed so RANDOM of you to say that , but it \'s a joke you \'ve been subconsciously holding on to ) for that sweet gratifying laughter . The thing that compels you to keep making more jokes .']
chatgpt_answers: ["Comedy writing is the process of creating jokes and comedic material. question: Why the Mona Lisa is so famous ? It just seems like some painting to me , why is it such a big deal ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["Well , to start , the Mona Lisa was painted by one of the most iconic figure in the times of the Renaissance which is Leonardo DaVinci . His anatomical studies of humans by examining and dissecting human cadavers and the Phi ratio ( eg . the Vitruvian Man ) has been used in his paintings , accurately representing the human body with near - perfect anatomical accuracy . It also introduced the three - quarter pose portrait layout . Previous paintings looked more stiff while the three - quarter pose used on the Mona Lisa looked more lifelike . Also , prior artworks had the same level of detail of the background and the subject . In the Mona Lisa , the background was more out of focus and the level of detail is significantly lower than the level of detail used on the subject , thus making it look like it was painted in the painter 's POV .", 'One is who painted it . Leonardo Da Vinci is famous for many reasons , both in art and science . It is also a very fine painting in its own right . But beyond a certain level , fame feeds on itself . It is famous because of its fame .', "I once had a nutty art teacher equate it to an early feminist piece . Her justification is as follows : All the portraits at the time were in the most lavish settings in the owners estate , dripping with every piece if jewelry the person owned to demonstrate wealth and power . In portraits , especially those featuring only women , they wore pieces that flaunted their husband 's wealth and affluence . Women were not individuals back then , but part of their husband 's amassed wealth and influence . The Mona Lisa is the antitheses of that trend . It is simply a picture of an independent woman belonging to no man , chained by no title or particular wealth , confined to no palace , and displaying what can be construed as independent thought ( the smirk and intriguing gaze ) . This was absolutely radical given the era . Not sure how common that interpretation is , but it always stuck with me ."]

question: How spiral arms form in galaxies Should n't it be like stirring hot chocolate powder in a cup ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['The speed of rotation of a galaxy is a bit weird to say the least . The outermost edge rotates slowly , and as you make your way inwards , the rotation speed increases . From the middle of the radius to the centre of the galaxy , speed again decreases . So what you have here is bits of matter ( gas , dust , planetary systems etc ) and stars which are held loosely together due to gravity . The matter bunched up into arms , due to the arrangement of the galactic magnetic fields . Due to the uneven rotation speed , the middle of these structures gets " smeared " all over the place , as the faster middle overtakes the slow centre and the edge . ps : Its a good thing we are living in a spiral galaxy , the other kinds of galaxies have virtually no heavy elements , hence , chances of intelligent life or even , higher forms of life is almost zero .', "Here 's an interesting and relevant simulation that may help to visualise the process . In a galaxy, these density waves are created by the gravitational forces of the galaxy's central region and the matter that surrounds it. As the wave moves through the disk of the galaxy, it causes the stars, gas, and dust to bunch up, forming a spiral arm.

question: what is 4 G , and why is it better than 3 G ? When I visit Orlando or Miami , I get to experience 4G. It drains my battery , but it is fast ! Is it because its 4 G ? Is it faster than WiFi ? Explain like I'm five.

Depending on your carrier , 4 G can mean different technologies and different levels of battery drainage ( although battery drainage also depends on a number of other factors ) . If you \'re with Verizon , AT & T , or Sprint , you \'re probably on LTE . LTE stands for " Long Term Evolution " and is the most widely used 4 G technology . It \'s really fast , and an upcoming update will make it much faster . T - Mobile is eventually going to launch 4 G as well . If you \'re with Sprint , you could also be on WiMax ; WiMax is basically Wi - Fi on steroids . It \'s very fast , but it \'s not very popular outside of the USA . If you \'re on T - Mobile or AT & T , you could also be on HSPA+ , which stands for " High Speed Packet Access " . It \'s basically 3 G but with a better internet connection . This is the network T - Mobile started calling " 4 G " . I suspect it will eventually be demoted to 3.75G. HSPA+ can download 84 [ Mbps ] ( URL_0 ) at its very maximum . Wi - Fi can go up to 150 Mbps , depending on the kind of Wi - Fi you \'re using . LTE and WiMax are capable of going faster than that , up to about 1 Gbps . Of course , these are * theoretical maximum * speeds , so you \'re definitely not going to see speeds like this on your phone . And , to any Canadians out there , if your phone is " 4 G " it \'s probably using HSPA+ . LTE phones are usually labelled as such . P.s . Corrections are welcome . I \'m not American . * * tl;dr * * see kevtice15 \'s tl;dr Edit : Network speed info', "4 G stands for Fourth Generation . It 's a new standard of wireless communication and it 's faster . question: Antioxidants and how they work ? And why I should take them . Explain to me like I am 5 what antioxidants are , how they work , and why I should take them . Also what are the best sources . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['[ Here \'s ] ( URL_0 ) a very good blog post written by Ben Goldacre about the subject , if you have his book Bad Science it \'s expanded and covered from pages 101 - 111 . Other people have explained the theory behind taking antioxidant supplements quite well , but in studies they \'ve been shown to not do much , or even be actively harmful . " Two large trials of antioxidants were set up after Peto \'s paper .... One was in Finland , where 30,000 participants at high risk of lung cancer were recruited , and randomised to receive either beta - carotene , vitamin E , or both , or neither . Not only was there an increase in death from lung cancer among the people taking the supposedly protective beta - carotene supplements , compared with placebo , but the vitamin group also showed increased death from prostate and gastric cancers . The results of the other trial were almost worse . It was called the " Carotene and Retinol Efficacy Trial " , or " CARET " .... Two groups of people at high risk of lung cancer were studied : smokers , and people who had been exposed to asbestos at work . Half were given beta - carotene and vitamin A , while the other half got placebo . Eighteen thousand participants were due to be recruited throughout its course , and the intention was that they would be followed up for an average of six years ; but in fact the trial was terminated early , because it was considered unethical to continue it . Why ? The people having the antioxidant tablets were 46 per cent more likely to die from lung cancer , and 17 per cent more likely to die of any cause , than the people taking placebo pills . "', "This article was posted on /r / skeptic a few days ago . It 's a good read . [ The Doctor and the Pomegranate : Antioxidants do n't work , but no one wants to hear it . ] ( URL_0 )", 'The microbiological reason for aging stems from the shrinking of telomeres in chromosomal DNA . Telomeres are long strands of DNA that do n\'t really do anything but safeguard against any " bad juju " during mitosis . As you grow older , variables like free radicals can damage cells by affecting them at a microbiologic level such as influencing the cell division process and possibly shortening telomeres . Again , this is just a theory and other variables affect the shortening of telomeres . However , antioxidants help fight against the effects of free radicals . Generally , people take antioxidants quoting its ability to downplay the free radical effects , and one benefit ( theorized ) is that it helps slow down the aging process . A common antioxidant is Vitamin C and you should be consuming that in fruits anyway - a good diet is better than you think .']
chatgpt_answers: ['Antioxidants are special substances that help protect our bodies from harmful substances called "free radicals." Free radicals are tiny particles that can damage our cells and cause problems like inflammation and disease. Antioxidants work by neutralizing free radicals and helping to repair the damage they can cause. They do this by giving up some of their own molecules to the free radicals, which helps to stabilize them and keep them from causing harm. There are many different types of antioxidants, and they can be found in a variety of foods and supplements. Some of the best sources of antioxidants include fruits and vegetables, especially those that are brightly colored like berries, oranges, and leafy greens. Other good sources include nuts, seeds, and whole grains. It\'s important to get enough antioxidants because they can help keep our bodies healthy and strong. They can help protect against problems like heart disease, cancer, and other illnesses. So, it\'s a good idea to make sure you\'re eating a variety of antioxidant-rich foods every day to help keep your body healthy and strong.']

question: " Second cousin twice removed " I do n't understand how people determine things like this . I honestly have no idea what a second cousin is or what " one , twice , three times removed " means . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["ca n't really get more clear than the diagrams here URL_0", "First , second , third , etc . cousins are at the same level in the family tree . The numbering refers to how many generations are between you and a common ancestor ( for first cousins , your common ancestor is your grandparent which has one generation ( your parents ) separating you from them . The once , twice , etc . removed refers to relatives that are n't at the same level on the family tree . They count the same in either direction ( up and down ) from your level of the tree . So , technically , your aunts and uncles are first cousins once removed , but so would their grandkids be . Your second cousin twice removed would be someone related to your great - grandparents , two generations away from you . So either your great grandparents ' kid ( at the level of your grandparents , making them a great - aunt / uncle ) , or your great - grandparents ' great - great - great - grandkid ( your second cousin 's grand kid ) .", "I 'm a Viriginian with a complex family tree -- nothing disreputable , but one set of great - grandparents had two children shortly after marriage , then a second set of two children 15 years later , effectively dropping the second set into a new generation . Suddenly the children of the first set were about the same age as the second set themselves . This created waves throughout the generations such that two 15 - year olds sitting at the same table in 1985 would have to figure out if they were once removed or twice removed . I decided that at age 8 or so , I would n't fight my mind 's natural inclination to ignore such titles as they were stupid . That decsision has served me well ."]
chatgpt_answers:
['Sure! A cousin is a relative who is the child of one of your parents' siblings. So if your mom has a brother or sister, and that person has a child, that child is your cousin.

"Removed" means how many generations away the cousin is from you. So if you and your cousin are the same age and have the same grandparents, you are first cousins. If your cousin is the child of your first cousin, your cousin is your second cousin.

"Twice removed" means that there is a two-generation difference between you and your cousin. For example, if your first cousin has a child, that child is your second cousin once removed. If that child has a child, that child is your second cousin twice removed.

I hope that helps! Let me know if you have any more questions.']

question: What a computer ca n't do Are there even limits to what computer can do ? If so , what ca n't they do ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['There are some limitations . For example , there is the famous Halting Problem . It is impossible to create a computer program that will scan other programs , and determine 100 % of the time whether or not they will halt or run forever .', "This is more of a philosophical question than a computer science question to ELI5 from an expert . There are a few parts : * * Can a computer eventually be able solve every math or well structured problem ? * * No , there are proven limits to mathematics where not everything you would like to be able to do can be done . The halting problem mentioned in another reply is one . Godel 's incompleteness theorem is another : every complex enough system will have things it can not prove . Additionally , there is the issue of being able to solve a problem but not having enough time in the universe to do so . The P = NP problem is an open issue in computer science about how many problems are like this , are there a ton of problems that are solvable but take a million years to figure out , or are there none ? * * Can a computer eventually do tasks that humans tend to be much better at , like recognizing objects or creative projects like art ? * * Every year the definition of what people are way better at than computers seems to shrink . It is n't chess , which was once a good example . There is software that can do facial recognition ok , software can understand speech . It is n't even captcas anymore . There is not a single area of day to day problems that humans do that would be always impossible for a computer ( I would argue ) , but there are plenty where the cost of developing software / robotics to do it would be impractical . * * Can a computer eventually do things that we view as very human , such use language to express itself fluently or having consciousness ? * * This is an open debate . Some view people as a type of computing system so of course computers could be everything that humans are , people just use neurons instead of silicon . Others see a uniqueness in humans and you ca n't make the jump from step by step programming to real thinking just by adding more processing power . Searle 's Chinese room paper is a good starting point to this argument .", 'A computer can not make decisions based on intuition . They have trouble interpreting data in ways they have not been explicitly programmed to , although machines like [ Watson ] ( URL_0 ) - the Jeopardy - playing computer - are making significant strides in that area . Computers can not decipher handwriting or natural patterns with nearly the ease and speed of the human brain . A computer can not even accurately identify a human face from a drawing or painting of one , which even an infant can do .']
chatgpt_answers: ['Computers can do many things, but they are not capable of everything. There are some tasks that computers cannot do because they require human-like abilities that computers do not possess. For example, computers are not able to think, feel, or experience things in the same way that humans do. They also do not have the ability to make decisions or solve problems in the same way that humans do. Computers are also limited by the instructions that they are given. They can only do what they are programmed to do, and they are not able to think for themselves or come up with new ideas on their own. Additionally, computers can only work with the information and data that they are given. They are not able to learn or understand new things unless they are specifically told to do so by a human or another computer. Overall, while computers are very powerful and capable of performing many tasks, they are not able to do everything that humans can do. They are limited by their programming and their inability to think, feel, and experience things in the same way that humans do.']

question: What is the difference between sex and gender ? What is the difference between sex and gender ? What is the difference between transgender , transsexual , and transvestite ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['Sex is a biological attribute . Gender is an identity attribute . A person with can be biologically male ( sex ) , but they can identify as female ( gender ) . Of course the statement " i am male / female " can then be controversial , politically speaking and even ambiguous since you do n\'t know which is being referred to .', 'Sex is assigned at birth . The doctor looks at the genitalia and writes " male " or " female " on the birth certificate . Usually it \'s a clear distinction , but there are people who are born intersex whose genitalia are not male or female , and it \'s up to the doctor \'s judgment to pick one . We learn in biology class that male is XY and female is XX , but there are also genetic abnormalities where someone can be X ( Turner syndrome ) or XXY ( Kleinfelter syndrome ) , so even that distinction is blurry . Of course , in 99 % of cases , sex is easy to determine , but I feel like this is worth mentioning . It \'s difficult to come up with an objective definition of sex , basically . Gender is how a person feels and/or chooses to represent themselves to the outside world . In the vast majority of cases , gender and sex are the same thing , which is why historically the terms have been used entirely interchangeably . Someone who feels that they are a woman but was assigned " male " at birth is transgendered , as is a person who was assigned female at birth but feels that they are a man . Transsexual is used somewhat interchangeably , but it \'s sometimes used to describe someone who has undergone surgery to alter their genitalia whereas " transgender " does not necessarily mean that they \'ve had surgery . A transvestite is someone who identifies as one gender but dresses like the opposite gender , like a drag queen . Someone who is transgender is not a transvestite , they \'re very different things . RuPaul is a man in both sex and gender , he just likes to dress up like a woman . There are also people who feel that gender is more complicated than " you \'re a man or woman . " Gender - queer , agender , gender - fluid , androgynous , that stuff . They all mean different things , but none of them are " male " or " female . " edit : I should also mention that if you accidentally refer to a transgender person as a " transvestite , " they \'ll be really offended . " Transvestite " says " you are a man that likes to dress up as a girl , " so it will really piss someone off if they feel that they genuinely are a girl . second edit : I should add that textbooks generally define sex in terms of which role an individual plays in reproduction . In mammals and reptiles , for example , the female receives genetic material from the male and gives birth to offspring ( either as an egg or as live young ) . The problem with defining it that way is that it does n\'t really leave room to define the sex of individuals that are sterile at birth , nor does it clearly define any sort of * permanence * since there are a number of hermaphroditic species .', '[ This is a good infographic ] ( URL_0 )']
chatgpt_answers: ["Sure! Sex refers to the physical characteristics that make a person a male, female, or intersex. These characteristics include things like the person's genes, hormones, and reproductive anatomy. Gender refers to the social and cultural roles that society assigns to men, women, and non-binary people based on their sex. These roles can include things like how a person is expected to dress, behave, and interact with others. Transgender refers to people whose gender identity is different from the sex they were assigned at birth. For example, a person who was assigned male at birth but who identifies as a woman is a transgender woman. Transsexual refers to people who have undergone surgery to change their physical sex, such as by getting a penis or vagina. Transvestite is an outdated term that is not used much anymore. It referred to people who liked to wear clothes that are usually worn by people of the opposite sex. I hope that helps! Do you have any other questions about this?"]

question: What exactly causes the explosion to be so large when a nuclear bomb is detonated ? Can splitting an atom really cause an explosion to be that large ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["Yes , it can , but it 's not just splitting one atom ; it 's the chain reaction of all of the atoms . The nucleus of an atom is held together by what 's called binding energy . When it gets split , you now have 2 or more nuclei , but the total binding energy of the parts is lower than the binding energy of the initial single nucleus . That extra energy is the explosion . The fission of one atom of Plutonium 239 generates 3.318 ×10 ^ -11 Joules , which is tiny , but single kilogram of plutonium contains 2.46x10 ^ 24 atoms . Bonus trivia : Most modern nuclear weapons use fusion as their primary energy source . A small fission primary sets of a chain reaction where lighter elements are fused together to make heavier ones , releasing even more energy that fission can .", 'The simple answer is yes . Modern bombs run on fusion energy , but the principle of converting rest mass into energy remains the same . Other bomb methods are converting chemical bond energy into energy , and on the scale of nuclear physics chemical bonds are weak . Really weak . How powerful ? Well a modern hydrogen nuke gives out over 1 megaton of energy , or 1 billion tons of TNT . It is difficult to even explain how insanely powerful that is . If you want to be scared then the largest one ever test was a 50 megaton nuke . This is a great little app to show you the effects these bombs would have URL_0', "They are n't splitting just one atom . The bomb splits many millions , and this releases a lot of energy ."]
chatgpt_answers: ['When a nuclear bomb is detonated, it releases a huge amount of energy. This energy is released when the atomic nucleus of an atom is split into two smaller nuclei. This process is called nuclear fission, and it can release a lot of energy because the nucleus of an atom contains a lot of energy. When the nucleus is split, the energy that was holding it together is released, and this energy can be used to create an explosion. So, to answer your question, splitting an atom can cause an explosion to be very large because it releases a lot of energy.']

question: What is happening in our brains when we think ? How does a series of nerve impulses become a complex thought ? And why we can we sort of " feel " our thoughts somewhere in our head instead of , let 's say , our feet ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['Being a cognitive / neuroscience researcher myself , i have to say that this is a thing no one fully understands . The brain and how it deals with sensory input , how it ultimatively makes sense of the world is an insanely complex process . In fact , we do n\'t even fully understand how you can look at an apple and say " that is an apple " , so do n\'t even ask about how we understand abstract and complex topics . Some basic tasks a human is capable of , such as identifying types of fruit really really fast ( within milliseconds ) and really really well ( over 95 % accuracy ) are we now trying to teach computers , as some researchers hope that this will give us some insight on how we do such things with our brain , but only to figure that it is extremely difficult and needs like a shitload of data ( like more data than any human needs or ever gets , we do n\'t have to look at 10\'000 apples until we are able to distinguish it from a banana ) , and only leads to limited results . Moreover , a software that can identify types of fruit can not learn to identify types of animals without having to re - train it completely ... Sometimes researchers go and look what happens inside the brain using imaging technology . But even that only holds limited results . It \'s like clamping some sensors on your computer measuring the electricity that floats trough various parts , and then let the computer do various things to see whether one can identify which parts relate to which tasks - only to see that many parts are involved in many tasks yet we still do n\'t see what they are doing because only knowing that they do something does not tell you what it is , or how the information that is passed between the parts is represented .', 'Unfortunately , despite the efforts of a vast number of research fields , we have no idea . Due to its importance research is ongoing , but nothing resembling a meaningful answer currently exists .', '> And why we can we sort of " feel " our thoughts somewhere in our head instead of , let \'s say , our feet ? Not sure about the title question but I \'d say the answer to this part has something to do with our brain being in our head and not in , let \'s say , our feet']
chatgpt_answers: ['When we think, our brains are processing and organizing information. Our brains are made up of billions of tiny cells called neurons, which communicate with each other through electrical and chemical signals. When we think about something, our neurons send messages back and forth to each other very quickly, forming patterns and connections that help us understand and remember things.\\n\\nAs for why we "feel" our thoughts in our head, it\'s because that\'s where our brain is located. Our brain is the organ that controls all of our thoughts and actions, so it makes sense that we would feel those things happening in our head. Our feet and other parts of our body don\'t play a direct role in thinking and processing information, so we don\'t typically feel those things happening there.']

question: What is minecraft ? * Edit * Thanks for such an overwhelming response . I 'll check it out Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["Minecraft is a game based around pure imagination with a backstory of survival . There is no goal but to survive the nights and you start off with no introduction and no tools . Using nothing but your bare fists , you must harvest materials from the world and make tools and structures to survive . During the day , you are free to do what you please , but at night , monsters come out . The graphics are terrible by design . It 's part of the charm and artistic style of the game . It 's only noticeable for about ten minutes anyway , and then you start ignoring it . The obsession is for many reasons . The game does n't give you a specific goal , which leaves many ways for people to make a living in Minecraft . People can be hunting nomads , or castle dwellers , or cave explorers , or inventors . Everybody finds something to do in the game that really appeals to them , and since the world in Minecraft is completely random , with completely random events , every single session is different . No two scenarios are exactly the same .", "Minecraft is a game coded entirely in Java made by ' Notch ' . The game is graphically simple purely because that is the way it was intended to be . It gives it a nice style . The obsession is because it 's addictive . It 's addictive because , well , it just is really . You can play a demo of it , downloaded from URL_0 The game is an open world adventure . Build what you want etc .", 'It \'s a game that relies on a few aspects . * Imagination : The game gives you no purpose at all . Anything you do in the game is because of your creativity niggling at you . * [ Small rewards :] ( URL_1 ) The game offers small frequent victories to the player to keep them enticed . Whether it be punching the first tree , crafting something new , killing a monster and getting an item from it , finding ore underground . The whole point is to not space the small feeling of success out too much to keep the player hooked . * Graphics : While I understand people \'s issues with the graphics , I also feel that it \'s a contributor to the game \'s success . With modern games , graphics do most of the thinking for you , trying to make it as real as possible . Minecraft does the opposite . Gives a basic world , which you can mold to your will , letting your imagination take over . [ \\[1\\ ] ] ( URL_0 ) [ \\[2\\ ] ] ( URL_2 ) are good examples I feel . When looking at it , you do n\'t see a blocky ass game , you see an epic cathedral that took someone days to build . With a realistic game you \'d poke at the flaws , minecraft graphics are all flaw , so you do n\'t worry about it , you look at what the person was trying to create . All in all , the game is what you make of it . You \'d be surprised how many disbelievers that vehemently mock the game I \'ve turned to loving it just by playing the game around them . You realise that they \'re watching over your shoulder and you just include them little by little until the day when they ask " So ... when you gon na play minecraft next ? " :D']
chatgpt_answers: ['Minecraft is a video game that allows players to build and explore virtual worlds made up of blocks. In the game, players can gather resources, craft items, and build structures using blocks of different materials. They can also fight monsters and other creatures, and explore a variety of landscapes, including forests, caves, and oceans. The game is called "Minecraft" because it is set in a virtual world made up of blocks, or "mines," that players can mine (dig up) and then use to build whatever they can imagine. There are several different modes in the game, including survival mode, where players must gather resources and fight off monsters to stay alive, and creative mode, where players have unlimited resources and can focus on building and creating. Minecraft is popular with players of all ages because it is easy to learn and allows players to be creative and explore their own virtual world. It is also often used in educational settings as a tool to teach kids about science, math, and other subjects.']

question: Explain the rules of Cricket to me please ! What are the core rules of gameplay ? What is the difference between Test Matches and the other , shorter matches ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["there are 11 players on each side , played on a big oval pitch ( a field with grass on ) . In the middle of the oval is a pale strip , where the bowler throws a cricket ball at a team of batsmen from the other side . He 's trying to smash the three wooden poles called wickets , with the ball , but sometimes the bowler tries to make the batsmen hit it in the air so that the bowlers teammates can catch the ball . If they catch the ball while it 's in the air , before it 's hit the ground , the batsman is out . The batsman tries to score runs . He hits the ball in different ways so that he and his teammate at the other end of the strip can run back and forward between the wickets and score runs . If he hits it off the pitch without it hitting the ground , he does n't have to run because he gets 6 runs automatically , and no more . If he hits it off the pitch but it DOES hit the floor , he gets 4 runs automatically , but no more . The bowler , and the fielders try to catch the ball and throw it back while the batsmen are out of their ' crease ' , which is a little safe zone they stand in next to the wicket . It 's a line drawn in white . If the batsmen gets put out by the other team , then one of the other 11 players takes up his place . In theory , they should go through all 11 players , and that brings an end to the ' innings ' . Innings can end early because the batting side can say ' we 've had enough ' , or because of bad weather . The bowler is allowed to bowl 6 times . That 's called an ' over ' . Wide balls , and no - deliveries do n't count . In some games , the number of ' overs ' is limited to a set number to shorten the game and make it more exciting . There are a few different kinds of bowling styles . Some people like to throw it really fast to hit the wickets . Some people like to spin the ball and make it go in different directions to get around the batsman or make him hit it badly . The bowler will do whatever he can to try and trick the batsman . There are a few ways the batsman can go out . -Hit the wickets with the ball -The fielders catch a hit ball before it touches the floor -Leg before wickets . The ball is definitely going to hit the wickets , but it hits the batsman 's leg first . -When the batters are scoring runs , and are out of their ' creases ' ( batters safe zone ) the fielders hit the wickets with the ball -The batsman hits his own wickets by accident -The batsman hits the ball twice ( rarely happens ) -Deliberately touches the ball -After a batsman gets put out , if the next one does n't arrive by 3 minutes , he 's out too . After everyone has batted , the teams swap , and whoever has scored the most runs , wins the game ! ! ! Hope this is a good basic guide . edit : to include pitch explanation", 'One team bats while the other team bowls and fields . The team which is bowling tries to get all of the batsmen " out " in one of several ways : * Caught ( the batsman hits the ball with his bat or hand , and one of the fielders catches it before it touches the ground ) * Bowled ( the bowler manages to knock the bails from the stumps - the stumps are three sticks in the ground and the bails are two smaller sticks which balance on top of them . ) * LBW ( The ball hits the batsman on the leg , and the umpire decides that it * would * have knocked the bails from the stumps if he had n\'t got in the way ) * Hit Wicket ( The batsman goes full retard and knocks the bails off himself ) * Stumped / Run Out ( The batsman leaves his crease after facing a delivery and the fielding team manages to knock the bails off with the ball before he can get back behind it . The crease is a line 1 yard in front of the stumps . ) * Handled ball ( The batsman deliberately plays the ball with his hand , usually to stop it rolling on to the stumps ) . The batsman try to score as many \' runs \' as they can before they get out . A run is scored by the two batsmen ( there are always two on the pitch - one at each end ) running down the pitch and swapping ends before the fielding team can run either of them out . You can score as many runs as you want at a time - if you can run from one end to the other 150 times without the fielding team managing to knock the bails off , then you would score 150 runs ( although this would never happen ) . You can also score boundaries . If you hit the ball over a rope which marks the edge of the field , you score either 6 runs ( for clearing it without bouncing ) or 4 runs . The game is divided into \' overs \' . An over is a period of 6 balls bowled by the same bowler from the same end of the pitch . He bowls at whichever batsman happens to be standing at that end of the pitch at the time ( which can change from ball to ball if they score an odd number of runs from a shot ) . At the end of an over , another bowler takes over and bowls an over from the opposite end of the pitch . Simple logic gates take in typically one or two inputs and make a decision ( output ) based on those inputs . The 3 most basic logic gates are " and " , " or " , and " not " . The " and " gate produces an " on " message if /both/ of its inputs are on . The " or " gate produces an " on " message if /either/ of its inputs are on . The " not " gate takes in only one input , and produces an " on " message if its input is off , and vice versa . Here are visualizations of those gates in action , where bright green is " on " and dark green is " off " . The And gate , where one input is on and the other is off , produces an " off " message : [ X ] ( URL_9 ) The And gate , where both inputs are on , produces an " on " message : [ X ] ( URL_3 ) The Or gate , where either input is on , produces an " on " message : [ X ] ( URL_4 ) [ X ] ( URL_2 ) When both inputs are on , the Or gate still produces an " on " message : [ X ] ( URL_6 ) The " not " gate flips the message it receives : [ X ] ( URL_1 ) [ X ] ( URL_7 ) If you want to download this program to play around with gates and learn more , its called [ Logisim ] ( URL_8 ) and is totally free ! Long story short , you can combine many of these inputs and gates to do increasingly complex things . Are you familiar with amino acids , polypeptides and the significance of proteins ?', 'Every amino acid in the body is associated to a specific tRNA molecule . tRNA molecules have specific sequences of ribonucleotides ( A , G , C , U ) , and each one has a specific anticodon . An anticodon is a triplet of nucleotides that is complementary to a " codon " on mRNA . For example , AUC is the complementary anticodon to UAG . Ya dig ? So , mRNA molecule associates itself with a ribosome . Ribosomes are themselves made up of rRNA , but that \'s not important . What \'s important is that the complex forms , and the start codon on mRNA ( the first three nucleotides , almost always AUG ) , is exposed at the binding site of the ribosome . The tRNA with a UAC anticodon binds . This specific tRNA molecule happens to carry the amino acid methionine . A second codon on the mRNA is exposed at the binding site , and the complementary tRNA , along with its amino acid , is brought in . So we have two adjacent tRNA molecules bound to the mRNA , which is " clamped " by a ribosome . The amino acids on the tRNA molecules bind , and the first tRNA molecule is released . The ribosome then goes along the mRNA molecule , each time exposing the next codon in the sequence . tRNA binds , amino acids attach and the tRNA that was there first leaves . The cycle continues until a stop codon ( no complementary tRNA ) is reached , and the whole complex dissociates . At this stage you have a chain of amino acids with no particular shape or useful structures . Post - translational modification includes the folding and modification of this chain to make a functional protein .']

['Translation is the process that occurs in cells where information stored in DNA is used to make proteins. Proteins are important because they perform many different functions in the body, such as helping to build and repair tissues, carrying oxygen in the blood, and helping to fight off infections.

The purpose of translation is to turn the genetic code stored in DNA into proteins that can be used by the cell.

Here are the steps of translation:

First, a special enzyme called RNA polymerase reads the DNA code and makes a copy of it using a molecule called RNA (ribonucleic acid). This process is called transcription.

The RNA copy is then sent out of the nucleus (the center of the cell where the DNA is stored) and into the cytoplasm (the area outside the nucleus).

In the cytoplasm, small RNA molecules called ribosomes "read" the RNA code and use it to build a protein.

The ribosomes work like tiny factories, with each ribosome reading the RNA code and attaching the correct amino acids (the building blocks of proteins) in the right order.

As the ribosomes add more and more amino acids, the protein starts to take shape.

When the protein is finished, it is released from the ribosome and can go on to perform its specific function in the cell.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.']

question: Atoms Is there a certain amount of atoms ? Or are there somehow forming more atoms ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["The number of atoms in the universe is actually decreasing ( but the total mass of all the atoms stays the same ) Several hundred thousand years after the big bang , the universe finally cooled down enough for the energy to begin to condense into atoms . Most of these were hydrogen atoms , with some helium , and a tiny amount of lithium . All of these atoms are very small and light compared to other atoms . Slowly , those atoms began to coalesce into stars because of their mutual gravitational attraction to one another . Inside these stars , the pressure and temperature were so great that the hydrogen atoms began fusing together into helium atoms . This results in a large release of energy ( this is what causes stars to shine ) , as well as reducing the number of atoms ( two hydrogens become one helium ) , without changing the total number of subatomic particles ( a helium has two - hydrogens ' worth of protons , neutrons , and electrons ) . This process continued , with helium fusing to form carbon , carbon fusing to form even heavier elements , etc . More energetic processes , such as supernovas , required to fuse anything heavier than iron . This process continued for a while , and is still going on today . In fact every single atom in the universe that is n't hydrogen , helium , or lithium was formed inside a star .", "Atoms are composed of other particles ( protons , neutrons , and electrons ) , so there is no fixed number of them in the universe . One element ( a type of atom , like oxygen or hydrogen ) can change into another type , or even split into two atoms . The particles that atoms are made of can also be created and destroyed by a variety of physical processes , so we ca n't even say that there 's a fixed amount of matter in the universe .", 'Atoms come and go . They are structures composed of much smaller fundamental units called Baryons and Leptons . These units can break apart under the right circumstances and atoms decay into their constituent parts . Similarly , under the right circumstances , atoms can be formed from the constituent parts . The total number of atoms in the universe at any given moment therefore fluctuates .']

There are a limited number of atoms in the universe, but they can combine with each other in different ways to form new substances. For example, when two atoms of hydrogen combine with one atom of oxygen, they form a molecule of water.

Atoms can also be split apart, a process called nuclear fission. When atoms are split, they release energy and can form new atoms. However, this process is not the same as creating new atoms from nothing. The total number of atoms in the universe remains the same, but they are just rearranged in different ways.

I hope this helps to explain!']

question: What exactly happens during electrocution ? I know that electrocution is bad and everything but i never really understood why Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ["Good question ! First lets dive into what exactly electrical current is . For the purposes of this explanation , it 's the flow of any charged atomic particle , such as electrons , or ions in solution . Ions include things like Sodium , potassium , calcium and chloride . The cells in your body that are capable of ' firing ' such as neurons , and muscles , pay a lot of attention to these ions . As you may know , cells are mostly water , and have a membrane surrounding them , made up of fatty acids . Water with ions conducts electric current really well , fatty acids do not . You can think of your cells , as kind of being like a battery , in that they have high levels of potassium ( + ) and chloride ( - ) on the inside of the cell . They actively exclude Sodium ( + ) , and selectively allow calcium(++ ) inside . Cells like neurons , regulate the ratio of ions inside / outside , and they try to maintain electroneutrality . Phrased differently , the number of positive charges inside the cell , should equal the number of negative charges inside the cell . If you get electrocuted , suddenly there is a huge amount of negative charge ' outside ' the cells , going into the cells and that really messes up the whole system through some very complicated elecrophysics beyond this discussion . The other major source of more understandable and relatable death and horror , is through resistance . When electricity is flowing through an electrical wire , there is some measure of resistance in that wire . It is usually very low , but there is some mild resistance that becomes significant . If you 've ever touched an insulated electrical wire , or put your hand on an electrical transformer , you 'll notice that it is significantly warm . As electrical current encounters resistance , it generates heat ; just like moving a physical object generates friction ( heat ) , electrical movement generates electrical friction , ergo- heat . The amount of heat is a matter of how much resistance you have , and how much electricity you are trying to move . As an electrical conductor , you are n't that great , and you have a fair amount of resistance . If you have a lot of electricity you 're trying to move ... like say a downed power line , you are going to generate a very large amount of heat , extremely quickly ; and it will literally cook you . If you 're trying to move a much more reasonable amount of electricity , such as licking a nine volt battery , the heat is n't the aspect you notice . You notice your taste bud / pain neurons getting annoyed and telling you to stop . Does that help ?", 'Your neurons use electricity to communicate . If you get shocked , your neurons might treat it as if a signal needed to be sent . So it triggers randomly . Your muscles might tense up in opposite directions , and injure it self . All the neurons firing in your brain is basically a seizure , so if your brain gets shocked all the neurons might fire . Also electricity that is strong enough might burn the things it passes through . This means it might burn the inside of your body .', 'Electrocution is death caused by electrical current flowing through the body . Electrical current is the movement of charge . So , we need to understand how the movement of charge through the body can kill a human . First , the human body has electrical resistance to the flow of current moving through it . When current flows through a resistor , heat is generated ( this is how heat is generated in an electric stove , or a hairdryer ) . A large enough current flowing through the body will cause substantial burns to the tissue through which the current flows . This in and of itself can kill a person , either directly , when large thermal damage is done to a major organ , like the heart or the brain , or indirectly , when the electrocuted person suffers thermal damage over a large enough portion of their body , resulting in infection and/or an electrolyte imbalance . Second , both muscles and nerves maintain a electrochemical gradient across their cell membranes . This electrochemical gradient is required for nerves to " fire " ( i.e. carry information along a nerve ) and for muscles to contract . Death can occur when current flows through / near the heart muscle , disrupting the electrochemical gradient required for normal heart function . The current then causes a heart attack(cessation of the heartbeat , or an irregular heart beat that impairs the ability of the heart to normally pump blood ) . Death can also occur if a large electrical current flows through the brain , causing massive disruption of the normal functioning of the brain , and seizures . A normally functioning brain is required to signal the diaphragm to contract , the mechanism for breathing . A large electrical current though the brain can cause a cessation of breathing , resulting in death by hypoxemia ( insufficient oxygen content in arterial blood ) .']
chatgpt_answers: ["Electrocution is when a person is killed or severely injured by an electric shock. When a person is electrocuted, electricity flows through their body, causing damage to their tissues and organs. This can happen if a person touches a live wire or electrical outlet, or if they come into contact with electricity in some other way.Electricity is a type of energy that can move through materials that allow it to flow easily, like metal. When electricity flows through a person's body, it can cause the muscles to contract, which can make it difficult for the person to move or breathe. It can also cause the heart to stop beating, which can be deadly.Overall, electrocution is dangerous because it can cause serious injury or death by disrupting the normal functioning of the body's tissues and organs. It's important to be careful around electricity and to follow safety guidelines to avoid accidents."]

question: How does software physically interact with hardware How does the software actually control processes in the hardware and interact with it . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['Software does not " physically " interact with the hardware . Software is a way in which the hardware operates to produce a change in the charge of transistors . The booting hardware prepares itself for interaction between itself and other hardware when you first boot it up . This preparation makes it possible for software to make changes to hardware , which is really just hardware operating in a specific way to make other hardware react in a specific way . Eventually , your hardware reaches a point that ordered changes in your peripheral hardware ( typing ) causes ordered changes to your internal hardware . The software is n\'t really interacting in a physical manner .', 'Software is not something distinct from the hardware . Software is the state of the hardware . This state can represent either data or rules about how the hardware will manipulate its state so you can have programs . The hardware is made up of storage elements ( CPU registers , RAM ) and control circuits . The storage elements hold the states . The hardware can manipulate some of the state by moving it from storage to the inputs of the control circuits . These control circuits will then do different manipulations on other state such as addition , comparing or copying , or fetching another piece of state and applying it to the control circuits to make them do something else .', 'There \'s a huge number of way for the 1s and 0s stored in memory to " access " the hardware . I \'ve not done any useful work at such a low level for years now , but as far as I can remember , the main idea behind hardware interaction is through three mechanisms : * the CPU has a special instruction that triggers said interaction , and thus just calling it is sufficient to have the hardware do your bid ; * some addresses in memory are in fact " mapped " to some hardware , and writing to them triggers a function of the mapped hardware - or reading them allow to get a reply from said hardware * the hardware " interrupts " the current operation of the CPU , making it execute some code you registered previously to this interrupt As I said , did n\'t wrote assembler for a few years now , so I understand that Direct Memory Access and such may have change a bit of the way a computer works , but I guess it \'s still close to the three aforementioned methods .']
chatgpt_answers: ["Software is a set of instructions that tells a computer what to do. These instructions are written in a special language called code. The computer reads the code and follows the instructions to perform tasks or solve problems.Hardware is the physical parts of a computer, such as the processor, memory, and storage. The software and hardware work together to make a computer run.To control processes in the hardware, the software sends instructions to the hardware through a special piece of software called an operating system. The operating system acts as a go-between, translating the instructions from the software into a form that the hardware can understand and carry out.For example, let's say you are using a word processing software to write a letter. You type the letter on your keyboard, which sends the information to the processor (a hardware component). The processor then uses the instructions from the word processing software to store the letter in memory (another hardware component) and display it on your screen (yet another hardware component).I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any more questions."]

question: What does a college grad need to know about finding a place to live ? Renting , buying , mortgages , leases , apartments , townhouses , condos , houses , etc . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: ['You can rent a place ( an apartment ) or buy a place ( a house , a townhouse , a condo ) . If you rent , you pay someone ( often a company ) to live in their property . If you buy , you own the place and it becomes your property . When you rent , you sign a lease , which is an agreement saying " I will live here for 12 months and pay $ XYZ per month to do so . " After the lease is up , different things can happen : you have the option to renew for 12 more months , at a possibly increased price ( this is what happened when I lived in New York City ) or the lease becomes month - to - month , usually without an increase ( this is how I live now in California ) . When you buy , unless you are really rich , you need a mortgage , which is a loan from a bank . You go to the bank , get approved for a loan of $ XYZ , then find a place to buy --- a house , a townhouse ( which is a small house , usually part of a single building which has several such units ) , or a condo ( like an apartment , but you own the inside . A company manages the " outside " . ) . When you buy , you make a large down - payment to the owner , usually 20 % of the sale price . Then you take a loan from the bank ( a mortgage ) for the rest and give that money to the owner . You pay the bank some amount each month until the loan is paid off . Most mortgages these days are scheduled to be paid back in * * 30 years * * . Once you pay the loan back , you own the property . Until then , the bank owns it . The most important part of housing is figuring out what you can afford . People spent anywhere from 30 - 50 % of their salary on housing . In high - rent areas , like NYC , you can expect to pay a greater portion of your salary .', 'One tip : Living on your own is way more expensive than you think .', "You are going to be expected to do a large lump sum up front , for a deposit / first months rent and such . Make sure you have the money . There are scumbag landlords . I 've had two in my life already . Lessons I learned : Do n't be a pushover and trust warning signs . IMO a college grad should look to live close to work with a bunch of roommates on a short lease , ideally month to month . Do n't buy furniture ( this is really expensive , even for throw away low quality items ) , so try to find furnished if possible . I 've craigslisted * a lot * and you will find better and better places the more time you spend at it . Expect to spend at a minimum 10 to 20 hours looking for a place . If you want a good one , expect more than 30 , with at least 5 - 10 days worth of solid looking and checking throughout the month . Although I just told you to craigslist a lot , the really really good places will have postings > 1 month ahead of the actual vacancy . And there will be a ton of new places posted as the end of a month approaches . I also do n't even bother checking anymore around the second week that a month starts . Please please do NOT go with the first ' decent ' place you find . Good roommates is the best thing to look for . Then location . And then finally price . This is also the order of how I 'd rank the fun memorable places I 've stayed at . Buying is significantly more than renting . You should n't even really consider it unless you are sitting on a huge down payment . URL_0"]
chatgpt_answers:
['Finding a place to live can be a challenging and exciting process, especially for college graduates who may be moving out on their own for the first time. Here are some important things to consider when looking for a place to live:

Renting vs. buying: Renting a place means you are paying someone else to live in their property, while buying a place means you own it and can make changes to it as you see fit. Renting can be a good option if you are not ready to commit to buying a home or if you are not sure where you want to live long-term. Buying a home can be a good option if you have the financial means and are planning to stay in one place for a while.

Mortgages: If you decide to buy a home, you will likely need to get a mortgage, which is a loan from a bank or other financial institution that you use to pay for the home. To get a mortgage, you will need to provide information about your income, debts, and credit history, and you will need to make a down payment (a portion of the total cost of the home that you pay upfront).

Leases: If you decide to rent a place, you will sign a lease, which is a legal agreement between you and the property owner or landlord. The lease will outline the terms of your tenancy, including the length of the rental period, the amount of rent you will pay, and any rules or restrictions that apply.

Apartments, townhouses, condos, and houses: There are many different types of properties you can rent or buy, and each has its own advantages and disadvantages. Apartments are typically smaller, multi-unit buildings with shared common areas. Townhouses are attached homes that share walls with neighboring units. Condos are similar to apartments, but you own your unit rather than renting it. Houses are standalone properties that you own.

Other factors to consider: When looking for a place to live, you may also want to consider the location, the size of the property, the cost of living in the area, and any amenities or features that are important to you, such as a pool or a garage. You may also want to think about the commute to your job or school and whether you need to be near public transportation or other conveniences.']
